initial_story:
Thanks for joining our live coverage on an extraordinary day in court, with adult-film star Stormy Daniels taking the stand.

It was a tense courtroom, with Daniels warned to dial back her comments at times. Prosecutors were also told to limit their questions regarding the salacious details of her alleged sexual encounter with Trump (which Trump has denied ever took place).

Here's our full wrap of what happened in court today.

This page was edited by Tiffany Wertheimer, Lisa Lambert, Brandon Livesay and Phil McCausland. The writers were Sam Hancock and Sean Seddon, and we had Madeline Halpert and Kayla Epstein in court.

Court doesn't sit on Wednesday, so we'll be back on Thursday, when Stormy Daniels will once again take to the stand to continue her testimony.

Thanks for joining our live coverage on an extraordinary day in court, with adult-film star Stormy Daniels taking the stand.

It was a tense courtroom, with Daniels warned to dial back her comments at times. Prosecutors were also told to limit their questions regarding the salacious details of her alleged sexual encounter with Trump (which Trump has denied ever took place).

Here's our full wrap of what happened in court today.

This page was edited by Tiffany Wertheimer, Lisa Lambert, Brandon Livesay and Phil McCausland. The writers were Sam Hancock and Sean Seddon, and we had Madeline Halpert and Kayla Epstein in court.

Court doesn't sit on Wednesday, so we'll be back on Thursday, when Stormy Daniels will once again take to the stand to continue her testimony.

In court, Daniels was given several warnings by the judge to stop trying to "inflame" Trump.

The day began with Daniels being sworn in and asked to give her full name, Stephanie Clifford.

Daniels told the court she "entered into a nondisclosure agreement" with a company controlled by Trump called Essential Consultants LLC, which was created by Trump's then-personal lawyer Michael Cohen.

Under cross-examination, Daniels said she knew Cohen before she had an alleged sexual encounter with Trump. She said Cohen was a friend of a friend.

Asked by prosecutor Joseph Grubs to describe what happened during the alleged encounter with Trump, Daniels said: "It was just textbook generic."

Daniels said Trump asked her to "spank him with a magazine with his face on it" and said she did it.

She said Trump then pulled up his pants and said, "You remind me of my daughter."

Daniels said Trump then told her to "come work for me" and invited her to a party at the Playboy Mansion.

Asked if she knew what Trump meant by the offer to "work for me," Daniels said she assumed he meant work at the White House.

Trump's former personal lawyer Michael Cohen has pleaded guilty to eight counts of campaign finance violations, tax evasion and bank fraud.

Cohen pleaded guilty to paying Daniels $130,000 to keep her from speaking about her alleged affair with Trump.

Cohen said he made the payment "at the direction of a candidate for federal office" -- a clear reference to Trump -- and that he "acted in coordination and at the direction of a candidate for federal office" and "for the principal purpose of influencing the election."

Daniels said she and Cohen communicated by text message and phone. She said Cohen told her Trump would pay back the money she was owed.

Daniels said she had a phone call with Trump after the alleged encounter. She said Trump told her she was "beautiful" and a "good girl," and that he liked her.

Asked if she knew that Trump was married at the time of the alleged encounter, Daniels said she knew that he was married.

Asked if she was ever paid by Trump, Daniels said she was. She said she was paid for services rendered and said she was paid in cash.

Daniels said Cohen told her he would pay her "a little bit more than $130,000" but that she would have to sign a nondisclosure agreement.

Daniels said she agreed to sign the agreement, but she said she wanted to be paid in cash.

Daniels said she had a conversation with Cohen and that she told him she wanted to be paid in cash.

Daniels said she and Cohen then had a second conversation about her being paid in cash. She said Cohen told her to "go to the bank" and withdraw the money.

Daniels said she then went to the bank and withdrew the money, and then she and Cohen had a third conversation about her being paid in cash.

Daniels said Cohen told her to take the money to a hotel in Los Angeles where she was staying.

She said she then went to the hotel, and Cohen met her there.

Daniels said Cohen told her to go to a room, and then he and she went into the room.

Daniels said Cohen told her to "get naked." She said she did.

She said Cohen then gave her a "big, fat stack of cash," which she said was $130,000.

Daniels said Cohen told her to "put it in your purse." She said she did.

She said Cohen told her to "sign the nondisclosure agreement." She said she did.

Daniels said she and Cohen then had a fourth conversation, during which Cohen told her to "keep your mouth shut."

Daniels said she then left the hotel.

Thanks for joining our live coverage on an extraordinary day in court, with adult-film star Stormy Daniels taking the stand.

It was a tense courtroom, with Daniels warned to dial back her comments at times. Prosecutors were also told to limit their questions regarding the salacious details of her alleged sexual encounter with Trump (which Trump has denied ever took place).

Here's our full wrap of what happened in court today.

This page was edited by Tiffany Wertheimer, Lisa Lambert, Brandon Livesay and Phil McCausland. The writers were Sam Hancock and Sean Seddon, and we had Madeline Halpert and Kayla Epstein in court.

Court doesn't sit on Wednesday, so we'll be back on Thursday, when Stormy Daniels will once again take to the stand to continue her testimony.

In court, Daniels was given several warnings by the judge to stop trying to "inflame" Trump.

The day began with Daniels being sworn in and asked to give her full name, Stephanie Clifford.

Daniels told the court she "entered into a nondisclosure agreement" with a company controlled by Trump called Essential Consultants LLC, which was created by Trump's then-personal lawyer Michael Cohen.

Under cross-examination, Daniels said she knew Cohen before she had an alleged sexual encounter with Trump. She said Cohen was a friend of a friend.

Asked by prosecutor Joseph Grubs to describe what happened during the alleged encounter with Trump, Daniels said: "It was just textbook generic."

Daniels said Trump asked her to "spank him with a magazine with his face on it" and said she did it.

She said Trump then pulled up his pants and said, "You remind me of my daughter."

Daniels said Trump then told her to "come work for me" and invited her to a party at the Playboy Mansion.

Asked if she knew what Trump meant by the offer to "work for me," Daniels said she assumed he meant work at the White House.

Trump's former personal lawyer Michael Cohen has pleaded guilty to eight counts of campaign finance violations, tax evasion and bank fraud.

Cohen pleaded guilty to paying Daniels $130,000 to keep her from speaking about her alleged affair with Trump.

Cohen said he made the payment "at the direction of a candidate for federal office" -- a clear reference to Trump -- and that he "acted in coordination and at the direction of a candidate for federal office" and "for the principal purpose of influencing the election."

Daniels said she and Cohen communicated by text message and phone. She said Cohen told her Trump would pay back the money she was owed.

Daniels said she had a phone call with Trump after the alleged encounter. She said Trump told her she was "beautiful" and a "good girl," and that he liked her.

Asked if she knew that Trump was married at the time of the alleged encounter, Daniels said she knew that he was married.

Asked if she was ever paid by Trump, Daniels said she was. She said she was paid for services rendered and said she was paid in cash.

A group of teenagers is out camping in the woods. They decide to tell each other scary stories around the campfire. One of the teenagers, a girl named Sarah, shares a story about a haunted house she and her friends had visited.
Sarah describes the eerie atmosphere of the house, with its creaking floorboards and flickering lights. She tells how they had explored the house, only to find that it was haunted by a vengeful spirit. The spirit had followed them back to their campsite and was now lurking in the woods, waiting to attack.
The other teenagers are skeptical, but as the night wears on, they begin to feel uneasy. Suddenly, they hear a strange noise coming from the woods. Sarah's story had come to life, and the spirit was now stalking them. The group panics and runs for their lives, but the spirit is relentless.

She tells how they had explored the house, only to find that it was haunted by a vengeful spirit. The spirit had followed them back to their campsite and was now lurking in the woods, waiting to attack.
The other friends are skeptical, but as the night wears on, they begin to feel uneasy. Suddenly, they hear a strange noise coming from the woods. Sarah's story had come to life, and the spirit was now stalking them. The group panics and runs for their lives, but the spirit is relentless.
In the end, they realize that the spirit had been following them all along, and they must find a way to defeat it before it destroys them. Will they be able to defeat the spirit, or will they succumb to its power?
